Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Taking good photographs, editing them
I learned so much about how to take, edit, and print photos, as well as how to think critically about photography.
The ability to technically operate a camera, to "see" through the perspective of a photographer, and to discuss photography as an art.
I learned how to use my camera! And a lot about the history of cameras!
Developed a critical eye for critiquing and developing digital photographs

I learned how to operate my DSLR manually, adjusting shutter speed, ISO, and aperture to create high-quality images. I also was connected to a lot of different photographic traditions/histories and learned about the portfolios, visual languages, and shooting styles of many talented photographers. Finally, I learned a lot about my own visual style and how to productively grow and develop my image-making.
Understand how to use digital camera, print, and use photoshop
I gained a new perspective on artistic expression through this class. Creating art, while perhaps still difficult for me, was a terrific way to be adventurous in the classroom.
I learned how to look at the world through a camera and capture the beauty that I see in the world
Engaging, well structured. It would be better if more help outside classroom could be provided.
There is little to no structure in the course. We quickly strayed from the curriculum and it seemed as though we were making up our path as we went.
No weaknesses! It was just such a good and fun course. Anna is amazing. Take it if you can get in!

Strengths: I liked the informal, but enthused class dynamic and felt like I grew a lot in my ability to take photographs and make prints.
Weaknesses: A bit of disconnect between written assignments and photographic assignments. Wish that we had more crits with fewer images in each crit (we ended up combining two crits at the beginning due to timing issues).

strengths: artistic freedom, good and evenly spaced assignments

weaknesses: sometimes difficult to navigate technology. Maybe create certain handouts/cheatsheets for photoshop and printing processes instead of a verbal explanation that is more elusive
The strengths of this course are the subject matters. Photography itself was something I had little experience with previously, so gaining a foothold in that was very special.

strengths: this is exactly what I was looking for in a photography course for beginners, I loved it

areas for improvement: more structure surrounding critiques with professor and learning more about editing techniques
Yes.
I would, depending on the student. If they have high school experience in photography, then I would.
Absolutely. Take it if you can get in.
Yes! This was an informative and engaging course for me to develop a lifelong skill.  The workload was very manageable, and I made some photographs that I'm really proud of.
yes, awesome into to photo
I would recommend this course to another student. It definitely takes time to shoot and edit, but it is very rewarding in the end.
ABSOLUTELY!!! It was amazing!!
